title: Friday, 14th July, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
PM11:02am

Hi

PM11:02am

Sorry a bit late today

PM11:03am

You may think I was delaying opening the session just to eat up a bit of time

11:03 am
PM11:03am

Since there's little fresh going on

PM11:03am

But that's not true!

PM11:03am

Truth is that my Eikon was playing up, but it's fixed now

oh.

Victo Chu

PM11:10am

PM11:10am

undefined
11:10 am
BE11:11am

I think -- though don't quote me on it -- that Camper & Nicholsons has its office above the Davidoff cigar shop in Jermyn Street, which isn't the cheapest bits of real estate. Perhaps that's a potential saving they could make, I speculate.

BE11:11am

Anyway, what else?

PM11:11am

C&N need somewhere swanky to meet clients remember

But yes, what else

PM11:11am

?

PM11:11am

Er

11:11 am

PM11:12am

But I'm bored of Carillion

PM11:12am

Carillion PLC (CLLN:LSE): Last: 59.35, up 3.9 (+7.03%), High: 62.05, Low: 56.00, Volume: 14.52m
11:13 am
BE11:13am

This, from Gill Plimmer, yesterday , is worth a read.

BE11:13am

https://www.ft.com...-9a66-93fb352ba1fe

BE11:14am

Sources close to the company said that an emergency rights issue would take time to engineer given the instability in the share price and the churn in the share register. The company is exploring a range of other options, including a debt-for-equity swap, the source said.

The option of a purchase of part or all of the business has been downplayed, as rival British contractors including Balfour Beatty — the subject of an aggressive takeover attempt by Carillion in 2013 — appeared to rule out bids.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

That's down in paragraph 26 or so, though the wires reached it and flashed it about half an hour after publication.

PM11:15am

Straight to a debt-for-equity swap?

PM11:15am

Wonder how they'll price that

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Not sure how that'd be more simple than a rights issue given the equity needing issued would be a significant multiple of its current market cap.

BE11:16am

Shareholders would need to approve that too, no?

PM11:16am

That's a point

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Maybe HSBC can figure this out. I can't.

PM11:16am

Nor me

PM11:16am

So let's move on

11:16 am
undefined
BE11:17am

And while on yesterday's stories ......

AstraZeneca PLC (AZN:LSE): Last: 4,936, down 77 (-1.54%), High: 4,952, Low: 4,875, Volume: 2.16m
11:17 am
BE11:17am

........... still no clarity.

BE11:18am

Streetinsider (Omg smile) had a report overnight about Pascal exiting post the US close yesterday and the news coming with a profit warning. That appears misplaced.

BE11:19am

Well, I mean it is misplaced because it didn't happen. Whether the gist is true or not, dunno.

11:19 am
PM11:19am

Morgan Stanley saying Soriot will express his commitment to AZ with the figures

BE11:20am

They're house broker, which might or might not give them deeper insight into his inner thoughts.

PM11:20am

We expect management to reiterate FY17 guidance - and CEO Soriot to make comments on his commitment to AZN... We expect AZN to reiterate its FY17 guidance of total revenue to decline by low to mid single digit % CER (MSe -5%), and core EPS to decline by low to mid teens % CER (MSe -15%). We expect management to make comments on the anticipated sales trajectory for recently launched oncology products Imfinzi, Lynparza and Tagrisso. As well, we would expect CEO Pascal Soriot to make comments on his commitment to AZN, in the context of recent rumours of a potential appointment by Teva (see press articles here and here, and a note by our colleague David Risinger on Teva here). We are not aware of official company comments on this rumour which has materially impacted AZN's share price, Pascal Soriot being highly experienced in global pharmaceuticals and well regarded thanks to the company transformation he has engaged and which is about to be potentially completed.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

Results due July 27th.

PM11:20am

… Ahead of crucial readouts in the next 6-12 months with the MYSTIC trial for Imfinzi in 1st line lung cancer around mid year (See our note 'Gauging the MYSTIC mystery'). We would expect topline results to drive AZN up 10-15% in case of success and down up to ~20% in case of failure. We base our estimates on updated sales model indication by indication, including an NPV/sh analysis for each contributing line. We would see a potential failure and negative initial reaction as an entry point to play other upcoming readouts including the MYSTIC OS readout in 2H17/2018 (potential rescue), acalbrutinib in leukemia in mid-2017, ARCTIC for Imfinzi in 3rd line lung in 2H17, Lynparza SOLO1 in 1L BRCAm ovarian cancer in 2H17 and Tagrisso 3 FLAURA in 1L NSCLC in 2H17.

PM11:21am

Ok -- 27th

11:21 am
PM11:22am

Have some free Lex on the matter

PM11:22am

Executives of large corporations, especially successful ones, need to keep moving. Some climb their own corporate ladders. Others move regularly on to new challenges. All market eyes watch for signs of migratory behaviour, up or out.

AstraZeneca has one of the latter herd. Pascal Soriot has run AstraZeneca since 2012. Reports on Thursday that he might move to Teva of Israel knocked more than 4 per cent off the former’s value. Rightly so. Mr Soriot has done much for AstraZeneca.

PM11:22am

Securing his services would be a coup for Teva. It specialises in knock-offs of the drugs which companies such as AstraZeneca spend big money to develop. For a time in the 1990s and early noughties, generic makers showed the big pharma houses how to make money, churning out off-patent drugs cheaply. Over the past decade or so, major drug companies rediscovered an old remedy: investing in new pharmaceuticals. AstraZeneca was one of these, finding niches in areas such as immuno-oncology to cure cancer. Its shares have done twice as well as Teva’s since that era.

Mr Soriot got AstraZeneca to think big again. More emphasis on research was paid for by shedding businesses deemed non-essential to AstraZeneca’s future. Disposals have raised £2.7bn over the past five years.

11:22 am
PM11:22am

That river will eventually run dry though. So the market eagerly awaits test results from the “Mystic” trials on two of its cancer drugs, used in conjunction, versus chemotherapy. There are worries that Mr Soriot knows something and wants away. Assume not. Keeping back such material information from investors would surely mean much worse for AstraZeneca’s shares.

BE11:23am

..... well, on that latter point, there's simply no way AZN could be "keeping back such material information" because medical trials are effectively sealed boxes.

BE11:23am

The time between AZN getting the results of Mystic and the time the market knows the numbers will be measured in hours at most.

11:24 am
BE11:25am

Nevertheless........... we've argued in the past on here about the possibility that the potential of immuno-oncology might have been exaggerated to pharma shareholders.

PM11:25am

You have

BE11:25am

..... given it's effectively been abandoned as an avenue by the basic research side.

11:26 am
PM11:26am

Bristol Myers still be into it, i think

BE11:26am

Maybe, just maybe, it's not worries about Mystic specifically that we should be talking about but a broader concern among those in the know that IO won't be the pipeline puffer that's been priced in across the industry.

PM11:27am

hmm

11:26 am
BE11:27am

Anyway, here's Leerink to do the old "AZN takeover" line again.

BE11:27am

• Potential CEO departure is an overhang, but it could also put
AZN's independence at risk. A change in management would leave
AZN adrift, in our view; however, we note that rudderless ships can either run aground our be boarded by pirates. If MYSTIC is successful, we believe this gives potential acquirers such as PFE (MP) or NVS (MP) an attractive target to plunder.

BE11:27am

"rudderless ships can either run aground our be boarded by pirates" is an investment case of sorts, I guess.

11:27 am
undefined
BE11:27am

Onto today, maybe?

PM11:28am

Hey

11:28 am
PM11:28am

You know you joked about how the Imps bid rumour wold come back

PM11:28am

would

PM11:29am

Well now it has -- at that website we don't name

11:29 am
PM11:29am

You are clairvoyant Bryce

BE11:29am

It wasn't exactly a joke, more a trained nose for incoming garbage.

PM11:29am

Or an inspiration

11:30 am
PM11:30am

Blue Horseshoe -- you are in real danger of getting zapped

PM11:02am

Welcome to Markets Live

PM11:31am

Anyway, wider market seems to have woken up to the fact that most of these bid rumours recently at 100% made up

11:31 am
Imperial Brands PLC (IMB:LSE): Last: 3,486, up 5.5 (+0.16%), High: 3,524, Low: 3,465, Volume: 579.38k
PM11:32am

Now I've said that, Japan Tobacco are problem going to come in with an offer...

BE11:32am

The latest retread coincides (though I don't think mentions) JT's Mighty offer.

11:32 am
BE11:33am

Which chances the landscape a bit.

BE11:33am

And we noted a day or two ago as well. Let me grab some Jefferies on it.

BE11:34am

JT is negotiating to acquire Mighty assets in the Philippines. Implications for an Imperial bid? Firstly, the reported offer price is 45bn Pesos. At most this would add around 0.2 turns to JT's net debt leverage (not enough to prevent an Imperial bid). Secondly, it confirms that JT is still wanting to improve its positioning on a global basis through deals. Imperial gives distribution in an attractive US profit pool and improved infrastructure in MEA.

11:34 am
BE11:35am

We also wrote in our JT downgrade how we see an Imperial bid by JT as an increasing possibility over the next 12 months as a way of solving its structural pressures. The obvious question will be, what does this mean for that possibility? First, we don't think it prevents it financially. Given the tax liability hanging over Mighty it appears JT are acquiring them at a much reduced price. If the 45bn Pesos is correct (c0.9bn USD), even assuming no EBITDA at Mighty (likely once they pay tax on their brands they are making a loss), then this would only add around 0.2 turns to JT's net debt to EBITA which currently stands at 0.3x. Second, this further highlights their appetite for a deal and perhaps the urgency with which JT knows it needs to act to address structural pressures and close the gap on peers (given the brands and tax liability of Mighty, plus the current industry headwinds, would the company have taken this deal on if not under such pressure at present?). Maybe this therefore increases the chances of an Imperial deal, not reduce it? For us, Imperial is a perfect fit for improving geographical positioning and growth prospects. It gives distribution (and we would imagine litigation ring-fence) in a very attractive US profit pool (both cigarettes and vapour/heated tobacco) and also significantly improves infrastructure in Middle East and Africa which is the emerging region where cigarette volumes are the most robust (Imperial best placed across the space in this geography). We believe the major barrier in the way of a JT bid is competition issues and was confirmed as such in May (Reuters) when the CEO said "Specific names aside, deals that would be potentially problematic in terms of anti-monopoly regulation are not realistic". If these can be overcome we believe JT would be willing buyers.

BE11:35am

One day, Rodney. And then we can all claim to be geniuses.

BE11:35am

Spin back to 1986 or whatever, when we first wrote about it and claim the exclusive.

11:35 am
undefined
BE11:36am

In terms of today's movers ...........

BE11:36am

Ashmore, I think, was mentioned.

11:36 am
Ashmore Group PLC (ASHM:LSE): Last: 339.90, down 10.9 (-3.11%), High: 355.60, Low: 334.20, Volume: 978.60k
PM11:36am

Why is it down? I thought the figs were ok

BE11:36am

Numbers are fine. Not great, fine.

11:36 am
PM11:37am

ok

BE11:37am

Shares have travelled in advance of them.

BE11:37am

So as expected, we get a second consecutive quarter of net inflows.

11:37 am
BE11:38am

And as expected, investment performance has been okay. 2.9%.

BE11:38am

FUM $58.7bn, slightly above consensus but not impressively so.

BE11:39am

Guidance fine. "momentum in gross sales continued across the product range in the quarter and gross redemptions reduced again quarter-on-quarter"

11:39 am
BE11:39am

"Emerging Markets assets continued to deliver good absolute returns during the quarter and outperformed developed world fixed income and equity markets," etc.

BE11:39am

Have RBC to say it's in the price already.

BE11:40am

Conclusion: Ashmore reports its FY17 results on 7 September. Currently, for FY17, we forecast EPS of 22.8p versus consensus (per Bloomberg) of 22.2p (on revenue of £265MM and £267MM, respectively). Ashmore earns management fees in US dollars, while its cost base is largely GBP. While AUM is higher than we anticipated, this will likely be somewhat offset by adverse FX movements during the most recent quarter. Thus, we do not expect a material change in consensus expectations. Ashmore trades at 16.5x CY17E EPS (sector: 15.8x) and at 16.6x CY18E EPS (sector: 14.0x), and yields 4.7% its FY17E dividend (sector: 4.9%)

11:40 am
BE11:40am

And Cazenove to say it's in the price already.

BE11:40am

AUM over the quarter increased by $2.8bn (c5%) to $58.7bn which was marginally above our estimate of $58.4bn, and supported by investment performance of $1.6bn and net inflows of $1.2bn. While net inflows were slightly below our $1.4bn estimate, we do note they were spread across multiple strategies and not skewed to lower margin overlay/liquidity which was the case in the prior quarter. Overall, while flow momentum continues to remain favourable for the group, we believe this is reflected in Ashmore’s 15% premium rating (c17x CY18E P/E) to the sector

undefined
11:41 am
BE11:41am

While on the sector ........

BE11:41am

............. HSBC pushing Staberdeen

Aberdeen Asset Management PLC (ADN:LSE): Last: 313.00, up 1.9 (+0.61%), High: 317.20, Low: 312.60, Volume: 544.91k
11:41 am
Standard Life PLC (SL.:LSE): Last: 413.80, up 2.9 (+0.71%), High: 416.70, Low: 413.20, Volume: 1.06m
PM11:42am

Staberdeen -- very good

BE11:43am

Flows improving, defensive merger looking less like a desperate act.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Standard Life (SL) and Aberdeen’s merger builds scale, diversifies both companies’ businesses and helps offset revenue and cost pressures. The merger does not address all their issues, but it offers some revenue and net inflow synergies (which we conservatively do not incorporate), while we incorporate the GBP200m of pre-tax cost savings in our pro-forma forecasts which drives the operating profit margin improvement. We see the combined Group keeping revenue margins relatively stable at 44bps over 2017-19e by offsetting the low margin outflows from books in run-off with relatively higher margin gross inflows

BE11:44am

Currently, Standard Life shares imply no growth (vs UK Life: 1%, UK Asset Management: 3%) on a pro-forma basis. Our base case estimates (assuming GBP200m cost savings) imply 9% pa operating EPS (UK Life: 7% pa) and 10% pa dividend (UK Life: 7% pa) growth for 2016-19e, while these could be conservative if the Group delivers ahead of its cost target.

BE11:44am

Standard Life has seen outflows from its flagship GARS funds (8% of combined AUM) due to underperformance while Aberdeen has suffered outflows from its EM and Asian franchises (12% of combined AUM). However, there are signs the rate of outflows could be easing - GARS has recovered its performance in 2017 ytd, while investors have been actively allocating towards EM as an asset class since the start of the year. Both factors bode well for a recovery in net flows

11:44 am
BE11:44am

The GBP200m pa announced cost savings is included in our base case estimates – the cost:income ratio reduces to 56% in 2019e (vs 63% in 2016). We believe the cost synergies are conservative given both managements’ track record in past acquisitions, and the UK asset management sector average at 50%.

BE11:45am

SL (11.9x pro-forma 2018e P/Op E) trades broadly in line with UK Life (11.7x PE) but at a 33% discount to UK Asset Management (17.8x PE), while offering a 2017e pro-forma yield of 5.4%, ahead of both sectors (UK Life 4.8% and Asset Management 4.2%), and growing 10% pa over 2016-19e. We increase our TP for SL and Aberdeen due to higher estimates and slightly lower COE for Standard Life.

BE11:45am

So ................ that. There's that. That's that.

11:45 am
undefined
PM11:45am

hmm

PM11:45am

You know I did the story that triggered Standard Life's demutualisation

11:45 am
PM11:45am

In 2006

BE11:45am

I don't!

PM11:46am

We'd learnt that the FSA was all over them for their lack of capital

11:46 am
PM11:46am

Sandie Crombie, then deputy ceo, said the story was "the biggest load of bollocks I've every heard" -- to me directly.

PM11:46am

So we published.

PM11:46am

The FSA confirmed it

11:46 am
PM11:46am

Triggered the float

PM11:47am

And Sandie got promoted to to CEO and was showed with ££££

BE11:47am

Thumbs up

11:47 am
undefined
BE11:48am

Cripes, it's dull today.

BE11:49am

Japan cigarette market fell -11% in June? Do we care about that?

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Probably not, as it'd sink us back into the JT story.

BE11:50am

There's Sky, also, I guess.

PM11:50am

Oh wait....

11:49 am
PM11:50am

Breaking news

PM11:50am

Portsmouth is City of the Year

PM11:50am

PORTSMOUTH picked up three awards at the prestigious South Coast Property Awards last night including the top prize - City of the Year.

Portsmouth City Council's hat trick of awards also included Corporate Real Estate Team of the Year.

Council project Dunsbury Park was also named Business Park of the Year at the glitzy event hosted by BBC journalist Jeremy Vine at the Ageas Bowl, in Southampton.

Awards chairman David Murray said: “Congratulations to Portsmouth - not only for winning City of the Year, but for securing Business Park of the Year for Dunsbury Park.

"In addition, it was good to see the council’s real-estate team being recognised in the Corporate Real Estate Team category for the council’s innovative work in realising the value of commercial property and ploughing the proceeds back into social measures to benefit the city’s population.

"Donna Jones and her team should be rightly proud of their achievements.”

11:50 am
undefined
PM11:50am

Sorry, go on with SKy

BE11:51am

I'm not sure anything we say can compete with the prestigious South Coast Property Awards.

11:51 am
PM11:51am

(H/t tony tassell, btw)

BE11:51am

I'm guessing City of the Year is limited to the South Coast here? It's a bit like the World Series?

PM11:52am

hehehe

11:51 am
BE11:52am

In the sense that, in spite of the name, an American team always wins it. Anyway, Sky.

Sky PLC (SKY:LSE): Last: 970.61, down 4.39 (-0.45%), High: 975.00, Low: 965.00, Volume: 7.20m
PM11:53am

You have a theory here, don't you?

11:53 am
PM11:53am

Re Murdoch

BE11:53am

Well. First, incoming analysis about how, actually, a CMA stage 2 is Murdoch's preferred path and how, actually, it's all the old man's masterplan.

BE11:54am

Take the decision out of the government's hands, no further delays on an uncertainty, blah blah blah.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

Jefferies:

BE11:55am

Sky’s apparent decision not to offer further concessions on FOX-Sky to the Govt before today’s 5pm deadline does not diminish probability of deal completing. Rather Sky has concluded that any concessions offered now would not elicit an immediate decision from the Govt (given holiday season, Sept party conferences, weak administration), so the faster route to a final decision is to get CMA phase 2 review underway as swiftly as possible.

BE11:55am

CMA review takes the issue out of the hands of politicians. The basis for decisionmaking becomes legal not political. Whilst a CMA decision can be appealed by 3rd parties to the Comp Appeals Tribunal, parameters for the ultimate decision remain legal ones. This reduces the risk, in our view, that a snap election could influence the outcome. CMA process is 24 weeks extendable up to 8 weeks, potentially deferring the decision to end-Feb 2018.

11:55 am
PM11:56am

Cunning. Perhaps

BE11:56am

The main risk to FOX-Sky completion, in our view, is that the hacking trial coming up in Oct – which will focus on the activities of The News of the World between 2000 and 2010 – produces compelling evidence of wrong-doing. In these circumstances, Ofcom would probably come under pressure to review Sky’s fitness to hold a UK broadcasting licence (an issue that Ofcom has an ongoing obligation to review). In so far as News Corp newspapers and Sky TV remain clearly distinct, it is not clear that hacking trial outcomes could actually impact Sky’s licence. At most, Ofcom might rule that certain individuals should have their management influence at Sky curtailed. However, FOX might conclude that continuing to pursue a FOX-Sky merger (in a way that might be construed as bringing newspaper and TV assets close together) would elevate risks around another fitness test.

BE11:56am

Downside protection. At 970p, Sky trades on 13.4x/13.1x PE for cal 2018/19 and on norm. Equity FCF yields of 6.1%/6.9%. We believe that the sub-800p levels achieved last autumn does not represent standalone ‘fair value’, contrived as they were from a succession of underwhelming events that could have been handled better in our view. Since then, we believe that standalone prospects have been improved by Ofcom's WLA consultation (cheaper access to fibre opening up a realistic pursuit of 3m Sky TV homes that still subscribe to BT BB), transformed Openreach incentives (no longer framed to protect BT Retail) and BT’s diminished ambitions for expanding its TV product beyond sport. Heading into a likely CMA review, we accept that Sky lacks near-term upside catalysts, but would certainly look to take advantage of any exaggerated share price weakness.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

That's the consensus view, well expressed by Jefferies.

BE11:58am

Though maybe .... just maybe .... we could be cognisant of the possibility here that Murdoch has buyer's remorse.

PM11:58am

hmmm

11:58 am
PM11:58am

What makes you think that?

BE11:58am

He's in a better position than anyone to see Sky's current numbers.

PM11:59am

This is true

11:59 am
BE11:59am

The ones we've seen are pretty terrible, and that's before football rights rebidding comes into the picture.

PM11:59am

Could he have clocked your stuff on Kodi sticks?

BE12:00pm

There's been a huge crackdown on Kodi of late, though this stuff is always like screwing the lid on a jam jar.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

It's hard to tighten it so much that no-one can subsequently remove it.

BE12:01pm

Anyway, there seems to be a cognitive dissonance between the idea that Murdoch's buying Sky for oodles of cash and the idea that without the bid Sky would be pricing in structural decline.

BE12:02pm

So maybe, just maybe, he's going a bit cold on the deal. Maybe, if it collapsed, he woudn't be overly bothered. As I say, it's not a consensus view but it's not an entirely outlandish one either.

12:02 pm
PM12:02pm

Noted

undefined
PM12:02pm

Look at the time

12:02 pm
PM12:03pm

Let's close this

PM12:03pm

Thanks for keeping the conversation going over on the right

PM12:03pm

We're off

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

We made it! Somehow! It's like hitting the petrol station when the needle's been nudging "E" for 55 minutes.

BE12:03pm

Well done, ROTR.

PM12:03pm

Have a good weekend

12:04 pm
PM12:04pm

Bye

BE11:31am

The same stale stories come up again and again and again. There's a stopped-clock logic to repeating them -- someone's going to get lucky at some point! -- but it's not really terribly useful to anyone other than rampers.
